history.content:
I have not taken many classes in the Math department but the most popular among CS majors are 104, 110, 113, 128A, and 185. Additionally, 104 and 110 are extremely valuable for any serious about machine learning beyond the undergrad curriculum.

There are also quite a few EE/CS classes that are more based in math than programming, fostering learning math with engineering philosophies. EE126 and EE127 are perhaps the "math-iest" of the EECS classes here while still being geared for a CS mind. You might also appreciate the mathematical concepts of EE120, CS170, and other EE12X or CS17X classes. CS189, especially in the fall, focuses on the mathematical derivations of popular machine learning methods. CS188 also approaches AI with some mathematical perspectives but less so than 189. 

The Statistics departments also offer classes that will most certainly build one's mathematical maturity with topics that complement an engineer's skill. Namely, Stat 140, 150, 153, etc.

Speaking of Stats and CS, the Data Science department is exactly the marriage of these two concepts. Data 100, while not heavy in math, will certainly show how to integrate statistical concepts into programmatic design.

children.subject:
Yeah its a pure math class, but its a pre-req for a lot of Statistics graduate courses that can be tied into the field of statistical learning theory. If you want to do any graduate work in statistics (and skew your statistics to an AI/ML angle), then you need real analysis. 

I took math104 this fall and it was pretty brutal for me. I'd personally recommend first starting with Math110, Stat140/EE126 (whichever you want), EE127, CS189, etc to build your math skills. Then if you have time leftover, and you start thinking about the possibility of grad school, then check out  math104.

Although there's an important subtlety being made in this answer: if you wish to go to conduct theory research in ML, Math 104 is a very handy class to have. Its possible to develop the mathematical maturity required to conduct research without taking analysis, but I will say that such cases are very rare and most people will do so through taking analysis (and not just one, sometimes multiple analysis classes). Courses like EE127 are somewhat reasonable alternatives (but just as an FYI, in older times apparently convex optimization fell under what is called "convex analysis").

If you wish to do applied ML, however, then there really is little need for Math 104.
Interesting. That also explains why so many other math classes have 104 as a prerequisite.
Why would math 104 be valuable for machine learning? Isn't that class mostly proofs?

history.content:
Hello! I’m interested in strengthening my mathematical background in a way that impacts my ability to integrate it into CS. I would appreciate any suggestions for such classes.

Thank you!
history.subject: Looking for math classes that would help me be better at CS
